awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Tectonic and climatic forcing of hydrological systems in the southern Great Basin: Implications for ancient and future aquatic system resilience
awd_abstract_narration:
The southern Great Basin is among the most arid regions in North America. It has almost no
perennial streams, but does have >1,000 springs. These springs are islands of aquatic habitat
in an ocean of desert. Remarkably, many of these isolated springs contain diverse aquatic
ecosystems and even endemic species of fish, spring snails, and other aquatic organisms. The
presence of many aquatic species that can only survive in water is evidence that the springs
are remnants of a perennial drainage system, and the presence of endemic species requiring
intervals in the million-year range for genetic divergence are evidence that at least some
of these springs have never desiccated over the geological time scale. Aquatic biogeographical
patterns thus inform the geological and hydrological history of the region.

This is a project to expand the already-large regional biogeographical database and to use the combined
new and preexisting data to test models of tectonic and paleohydrological evolution of the
southern Great Basin. The PIs will focus on two timescales: that of the extensional breakup of
the region from the late Miocene to the present and that of glacial/interglacial climate cycles.
Extensive work has been done to understand the extensional history of the region, which started
in the eastern portion of the study area at ~14 Ma and migrated westward to the Sierra Nevada
front, driven by plate-boundary dynamics. They will simulate this evolution using a regional
quasi-3D kinematic/tectonic-geomorphic-hydrologic coupled model that fully couples movement
along faults, mass distribution, magmatism, isostatic compensation and flexural deformation
with hydrology and surface geomorphic processes, including erosion and deposition. The extensional
fragmentation of the hydrological system will be studied and groundwater flow, necessary to
simulate the resulting development of springs, will be an integral part of the regional tectonic-geomorphic-hydrologic model.
.
Modeled paleohydrologic histories will be tested against biotic data (aquatic biota inventories,
microbial and macrofaunal DNA, and genetic divergence times) with island biogeography theory.
The PIs will test for relations of hydrologic fragmentation chronology with endemic species and
for ecosystem diversity with spring resilience, as inferred from groundwater ages and climatically
driven modeling. They will use these results to assess and improve their tectonic/paleohydrologic models.

por.por_cntn:
Today, the Death Valley region is mostly severe desert - the hottest and most arid desert in the Western Hemisphere.  However, even on the floor of Death Valley  there are scattered springs and, remarkably, these contain entire aquatic ecosystems, even including fishes.  Among these is the iconic Desert Pupfish.  Even more remarkably, in many cases different springs contain differing species of pupfish and other organisms, indicating that they have been separated for very long periods of time.   DNA data shows that these different species all trace back to a single ancestor.  How did these organisms that die outside of water get across the desert landscape to these springs?  What caused the populations in the various springs to become separated from each other, so that they could no longer interbreed?  Is this amazing history an outcome of essentially random events over a long period of time, or can it be explained by external causes?

These questions are the motivation for our research project.  We have examined in detail the geological history of the region, using mostly the findings from previous studies, but also applying geochemistry and geological dating to reconstruct the geography of the area back to 12 million years ago.  We have focused on the history of when the geological faults became active.  We have also reconstructed the climate history of the area over that time.  We have put all of this information into a computer model that simulates movement of faults, uplift and downdrop of the land surface, erosion of rock and its depostion in basins, and the size and pattern of the rivers and streams through geological time.

Our reconstruction tells us that at 12 million years ago the entire region, today stretching from Las Vegas in the east to the Sierra Nevada in the west, was a broad upland that reached a maximum elevation of about 6,000 feet in between what are now Death Valley and the crest of the Sierra.  The climate was much warmer and wetter than today and groves of giant sequoias grew in what is now extreme desert.  Broad streams connected this upland with what is now the Colorado River drainage.  This landscape would have been favorable for the migration of pupfish and other aquatic organisms up from southwestern North America, where they originated.  

Our tectonic reconstruction and model tell us that at about 12 to 10 million years ago great faults formed between Las Vegas and Death Valley that allowed the region to rapidly widen in the east-west direction (Fig. 1).  These began to downdrop the Death Valley area.  Still later, between about 6 and 4 million years ago, new faults formed to the west, including the ones that now bound the Sierra Nevada on the east side.  This allowed the Sierra Nevada to begin to rise.  As faults formed between the Sierra and Death Valley, the formerly continuous streams were chopped into segments by the faults and what had been a broad slope was converted into numerous isolated basins in which the water drained toward the basin centers and escaped only by evaporation.  This disconnection was exacerbated by drying as the rising Sierra Nevada created a rain shadow.  

Both the faulting and the climatic drying converted a wide-flung stream network into short segments, and ultimately into isolated springs.  This geological history explains well the observed distribution of pupfish and other species.  They were able to migrate into the region through the continuous, gentle streams that prevailed under the humid climate and smooth landscape of 12 million years ago.  The progressive disruptions of this landscape by new faults and drying climate began to isolate the different springs, and thus different aquatic species, from each other.  A comparison of the length of time that different species have been separated from each other, based on the 'DNA clock', with the timings of when various fauilts began to move shows a marked correspondence.  

These results help to explain the observed pattern of different species of pupfish and other organisms in different springs, in which the DNA indicates that they are related to each other but also separated for millions of years.  This pattern probably was not produced by random events, over very loing periods of time, in which the pupfish and other species were by some accident transported from springs without the species to ones with them, as is frequently positied.  Instead, their patterns can likely be explained as a result of a geological history that ultimately can be related to tectonic forces originating from deep within the earth.  The interrelation of faulting from within the earth, climate change resulting from the faulting, and resultant impacts on the hydrology of the region explain the origins, evolutionary history, and survival of these remarkable organisms.
